body: cool many thanks for the repro case, I'll take a look
I've changed import-once to work out duplicates in a consistent way rather than relying on always taking the first file load that returns

Because I haven't tried it yet, the fixed outcome should be red?
On Feb 27, 2014 12:14 AM, "Luke Page" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I've changed import-once to work out duplicates in a consistent way rather
> than relying on always taking the first file load that returns
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/less/less.js/issues/1898#issuecomment-36213828
> .

Is this based only on node.js non - blocking,  or as well in browser.
On Feb 28, 2014 12:22 PM, "Max Mikhailov" notifications@github.com wrote:

> @pmonegan https://github.com/pmonegan
> Nope, it's actually black. The tricky part is that by default the @importdirective implies
> once http://lesscss.org/features/#import-options-once option, so the
> last occurrence of "variables.less" (set in "indirect-b.less") is not
> expanded hence the latest definition is @color: black; (because the last
> imported file is "override.less").
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/less/less.js/issues/1898#issuecomment-36379075
> .
I did not test in a browser, but it should be the same (and should not be affected by blocking/non-blocking stuff, unless there're some other hidden bugs of course).

Ok. I'll let you know if you haven't tested it by then.
On Feb 28, 2014 12:31 PM, "Max Mikhailov" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I did not test in a browser, but it should be the same (and not depend on
> blocking/non-blocking, unless there're some other hidden bugs).
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/less/less.js/issues/1898#issuecomment-36379973
> .

It doesn't block loading files it just changes when it decides on the
duplicate.

Currently out of 100 browser refresh tests (FF, IE11) , @import is doing
what it's supposed to do. Same code returned @color: black each time.

On Fri, Feb 28, 2014 at 12:38 PM, Luke Page notifications@github.comwrote:

> It doesn't block loading files it just changes when it decides on the
> duplicate.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/less/less.js/issues/1898#issuecomment-36380649
> .

issue.title: `inline` and `less` imports of the same name = race condition
Running build twice produces vastly different CSS output with less-openui 0.5.2
issue.body:
OpenUI5 version: 1.54.4 (with less-openui5 0.5.2)

Browser/version (+device/version): N/A

Any other tested browsers/devices(OK/FAIL): N/A

URL (minimal example if possible):  N/A

User/password (if required and possible - do not post any confidential information here):  N/A

Steps to reproduce the problem: 
1.  Run build of an OpenUI5 library project by calling grunt build
2.  Rename the target directory target.one
3.  Run the build again
4.  Compare the target and target.one directories

What is the expected result?  Contents of the directories from the two different builds are the same.

What happens instead?  Contents can be vastly different.

Any other information? (attach screenshot if possible)
In our case, the project being built has a reasonably complex .less inheritance/import chain.  There could be up to 5 levels of inheritance to a single theme.  For example, the inheritance chain for one of our themes (from the less files with least precedence to most) is:
base > sap_belize > sas_base > sas_corporate

It seems like less files are getting loaded or processed in different orders between builds.  We dont know if this has to do with the asynchronous file loading introduced between 0.2.0 and 0.5.2.  In our debugging, we put log messages in lib/fileUtils  before line 64, which is the fs.readFile(fileInfo.path, { line and before line 70, which is the resolve({ line and saw the following for base.less:

Debug statements when incorrect CSS generated:
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less

Debug statements when correct CSS generated:
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Reading file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\base\base.less 
Resolving file: C:\dev\master\htmlcommons-themes\openui-framework-themes\build\tmp\build\unpackedOpenuiCompileAndProvidedDependencies\resources\sap\ui\core\themes\sap_belize\base.less

When sap_belize is resolved last, the resulting CSS is as expected.  When base, is resolved last, the CSS is incorrect.  We havent investigated what happens in resolve, but it looks like the last base.less resolved is the one that takes precedence in the CSS output.

issue.title: [INTERNAL] add test case for nesting race condition
issue.body:
In less 1.6.3 there is an issue with the same imports across different
nested imports. E.g. if the same import is used in 2 different less
files the order of loading is not guaranteed.
To ensure reproducibility of this issue the build is run 50 times.

refs: https://github.com/less/less.js/issues/1898
